caption.p: Effects of acclimation temperature and test temperature on the locomotor performance of two frog species. (A) Jumping performance measured as the peak resultant jump force in X. tropicalis (N accl.24°C test24°C: 101; N accl. 29°C test 24°C: 98; N accl. 24°C test 29°C: 99; N accl. 29°C test 29°C: 102). For jump force, the interaction between acclimation and test temperature was significant. (B) Exertion capacity measured as the time jumped until exhaustion in adult X. tropicalis (N accl.24°C test24°C: 102; N accl. 29°C test 24°C: 103; N accl. 24°C test 29°C: 102; N accl. 29°C test 29°C: 102), acclimation and test temperature had significant but independent effects. (C) Jumping performance in X. laevis (N accl.24°C test24°C: 31; N accl. 29°C test 24°C: 27; N accl. 24°C test 29°C: 31; N accl. 29°C test 29°C: 26) showing only an effect of test temperature. Notches illustrate the confidence intervals around the median. Values indicated by the grey diamonds are the estimated mean values from our mixed-effects model.
